title: How to Get Close to an Introvert

steps.title: Introverts appreciate a private conversation.
steps.content: Introverts appreciate a private conversation. You probably won’t get much out of an introvert if you try to talk to them in a group setting. Instead, take them out for coffee or buy them a drink, just the two of you. [1] X Research source If you’re at a party or a group gathering together, try splitting off from the main crowd and heading somewhere a little quieter to talk.

steps.title: Let your introverted friend prepare for a meetup.
steps.content: Let your introverted friend prepare for a meetup. Instead of texting them 20 minutes before you show up at their door, invite them out the day before so they know it’s coming. They’ll appreciate the heads up, and you’ll get to spend more time with them. [2] X Research source Similarly, you should try to let them know if you’re inviting other people or not. Introverts often need a little bit of prep time if they’re going to meet new people or hang out in a large crowd.

steps.title: Most introverts appreciate activities where you can be alone.
steps.content: Most introverts appreciate activities where you can be alone. Instead of spending all your time together in a group, try to plan activities where you two can really connect with each other. Go places on your own where there aren’t a ton of people around so you can talk deeply. [3] X Research source Even just spending time together while you read or go on the computer can count as quality time for an introvert. Reader Poll: We asked 1073 wikiHow readers who've had a close introvert friend, and 74% of them agreed that the best way to get close to an introvert is by getting to know them as a friend first. [Take Poll]

steps.title: Hobbies help introverts rest and recharge.
steps.content: Hobbies help introverts rest and recharge. As you get to know your introverted friend more, try to do things with them that interest them. If they’re into gardening, go over to their house and help them pull weeds. If they love to write, read a few of their rough drafts and compliment them. [4] X Research source Try to listen to your introverted friend whenever they tell you about their interests, too. They’ll appreciate that you’re listening attentively!

steps.title: Eventually, they’ll open up to you, too.
steps.content: Eventually, they’ll open up to you, too. Some introverts have a tough time telling others about themselves. Get the ball rolling by letting them in on a funny story from your past or a little secret you’ve been keeping. [5] X Research source Instead of saying, “So, how was your day?” Try leading with something like, “My day was insane! My boss got fired and we had to scramble to cover all her work. How was your day? Anything crazy happen?”

steps.title: Pick questions that they can’t answer with “yes” or “no.”
steps.content: Pick questions that they can’t answer with “yes” or “no.” It will get them talking and keep the conversation flowing naturally. Plus, you might even get to hear a little more about their life. [6] X Research source For instance, instead of saying, “Do you like your job?” try, “How do you feel about your career path so far?” Instead of saying, “Do you like living in the city?” try, “If you could live anywhere in the world, where would it be?”

steps.title: Introverts are often great listeners, but not great talkers.
steps.content: Introverts are often great listeners, but not great talkers. If your introverted friend has something to say, really listen and take it into account. Introverts usually think long and hard about what they’re going to say next, so chances are, it’s important. [7] X Research source You might even have to ask something like, “What do you think?” to get them talking. Try to give them ample time to answer questions. Introverted people might take a few seconds to pause and think about something before they speak.

steps.title: Being introduced to your friends can be overwhelming for introverts.
steps.content: Being introduced to your friends can be overwhelming for introverts. If you want to make an introvert feel more comfortable, try meeting new people together. You can join a club, try out a new hobby, or mingle with people at a bar to make new friends who don’t know either of you. [8] X Research source It’s totally fine to introduce an introverted person to your friends and family members. Just try to go slowly, and don’t introduce them to everyone all at once.

steps.title: Crowded places can be a little intimidating for introverts.
steps.content: Crowded places can be a little intimidating for introverts. If you’re at a party or a concert and your introverted friend suddenly goes quiet, check in to see if they’re okay. They might need to step outside or to the bathroom for a quick breather before diving back into the party. [9] X Research source They’ll appreciate you checking in on them, which will probably make you two feel closer.

steps.title: Silence doesn’t necessarily mean anything is wrong.
steps.content: Silence doesn’t necessarily mean anything is wrong. Some introverts go quiet when they’re just listening or thinking about what to say next. Allow yourself to be comfortable with the moments of silence. Instead of saying, “are you okay?” every time they take a pause, let them break the silence when they’re ready. [10] X Research source An introverted person will probably feel grateful that you don’t push them to talk when they don’t want to.

steps.title: Many introverts need time to recharge after social interaction.
steps.content: Many introverts need time to recharge after social interaction. If you two just went to a party or a big gathering, give your introverted friend some alone time if they need it. When they’re ready to hang out again, they’ll come to you. [11] X Research source Different people need different amounts of alone time. Some people only need a few hours, while other people need a few days to recharge.

steps.title: It doesn’t mean they don’t like you, it just means they’re tired.
steps.content: It doesn’t mean they don’t like you, it just means they’re tired. Different introverted people need different amounts of alone time to rest and recharge. If you’ve been hanging out with your introverted friend a lot, don’t take it personally if they tell you they need some time away from you. Chances are, when you see them again, they’ll be rested and happy to hang out. [12] X Research source Many introverted people understand that it’s frustrating to hear a “no thanks” over and over. Your introverted friend will appreciate it if you don’t get mad at them for taking care of their own needs.
